SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name Louis Demay

Present Address St. Brieux, Sask.

Pioneer Address St. Brieux, Sask.

Year you came to Saskatchewan 31st January 1906

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 10

How many of these were bachelor's homes? 1

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Every Sunday in summer and sometimes during week days in winter

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? See above

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?
   First without an invitation but otherwise were receiving invitations at all times.
   What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Afternoons and evenings

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Could not help but staying as conversations were endless. Most of the meals were also made in the form of lunches which consisted of bread, butter and coffee.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)

Tiens, mais on ne vous attendait pas... Mais vous allez rester... À la fortune du pot. Justement mon mari a tué le cochon avant hier. Il y aura du pâté et de la saucisse...

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? Coffee-----coffee-----coffeeeee/// and sometimes the "petite goutte" which meant that the host had succeeded in keeping a little whiskey for a few days at least... or was it gin ????

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? Always somebody staying for the chores and sometimes babies were the deciding factor as to who would stay.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Buildings only, also making arrangements to bring some provisions from town.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

Buildings: four or five times during the year. Provisions. Almost every week but oftener in winter as sleighs could travel better than wagons.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Gatherings in one house when meals were served and dances started. Some cards were played but players had to quit when dances started in order to provide space. Naturally for dances, especially wedding dances, everything in the furniture class was going out, except one little heater... just in case. The cooking was then made in some granary or outbuilding.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. Less frequent beginning 1912 after an old store made of logs was used until a parish hall was erected (1927)

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? No. There was a tacit turn about but nothing on schedule. But always a movement of going and coming.

What about snacks? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Could not help but staying as conversations were endless. Most of the meals were also mad in the form of luncheons which consisted of bread, butter and coffee.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to make "preluz" used, or was some other expression common?)

Justement non mais je ne vous attendais pas... Je vous ai fait rester... A la fortune du petit temps, mais je ne vous ai pas invité hier. Il y aura du pain et de la soupe...

If no meal, what other refreshments might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?

Coffee --- coffeee/// and sometimes the "petite goutte" which meant the host had succeeded in keeping a little whisky for a few days at least... or it was "goutte" which meant the host had succeeded in keeping a little whisky for a few days at least... or it was "goutte" which meant the host had succeeded in keeping a little whisky for a few days at least...

5. Did the whole family go out? Or did someone have to "look after the place"?

Always somebody staying for the chores and sometimes babies were the deciding factor as to who would stay.

6. Did you ever have "these" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? buildings only, also making arrangements to bring some provisions from town.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "these" were for, and how often they occurred.

Billings: four or five times during the year. Provisions: Almost every week but oftener in winter as sleighs could travel better than wagons.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Gatherings in cute houses when meals were served and dances started. Some cards were played but players had to quit when dance started in order to provide space.

Naturally for dances especially wedding dances everything in the furniture class was going out, except one little heater,... just in case.

The cooking was then made in some granary or outbuilding.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. Less frequent beginning 1912 after an old store made of logs was used until a parlor hall was erected (1927)

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, - every two weeks once a month, once a month, etc.? No. There was a tacit turn about but nothing on schedule. But always a movement of going and coming.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built? 1927 (parish hall)

What material was it made of? lumber How large was it? 60 X 32

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? The Church

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? Village

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (for example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

Christmas concerts held and still held in schools from 4 miles away from Village otherwise everything centred on the parish hall.

10. When parties, dances, etc. were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? not as a rule

How were babies and small children provided for? from fifteen to forty

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? Village livery barn

11. What card games were popular in the early days? French Manille, Trois Sept, Ecarté. After a few years Euchre, plain whist.

Was there card playing for a prize? just a token

What dances were popular? yes

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Not enough room for old people to enjoy themselves. The friction was not much.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain Not a bit, on the contrary, it was not thought that harm was done to play on Sundays.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, pianos, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

9. When was your first community hall built? 1927 (parish hall)

What material was it made of? Timber

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? The Church

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? Village

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use your personal school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

Christmas concerts held and still held in schools from 4 miles away from Village otherwise everything centred on the parish hall.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? Not as a rule

How were babies and small children provided for? From fifteen to forty

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

Village livery barn

11. What card games were popular in the early days? French Neville, Trois Sept, Hearts.

After a few years Endure, plain whist.

Was there card playing for a prize? Just a token

What dances were popular? Yes

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. The friction was not much.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain. Not a bit, on the contrary, it was not thought that harm was done to play on Sundays.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? none here

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? yes
Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc. Not many done as newly wed were always giving dances of their own accord. One exception in 1918 when one man gave as excuse not to give a dance: My cousin in the old country died over six months ago. He was forced to give $25.00 to retrieve his horse and cutter and to get his bride back.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc. that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.
In one home the "quizz program" of the radio was already the go in the evenings. Otherwise card parties and conversations were very common.
Changes occurred just after the time the hall was built (1927) But the games were not so numerous after the village was erected (1914)

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community? Association Catholique Franco Canadienne de la Saskatchewan (still in existence) was formed as a branch in 1914.
Give the date and reason for it being organized. As a Provincial organization 1912. To promote the learning of the French language both in and out of schools. To arrange for the French curriculum in school and examinations etc.

one parishioner living at the extreme north east of the parish

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.  
   30th June 1913

26. Who organized it?  
   Church authorities

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?  
   Entire community (Parish)

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?  
   Yes

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?  
   Contests such as cigar smoking, foot races, ox races, horse races, Indian race, chuck wagon races, egg and spoon races, sack races, three legged races, nickels in saw dust, jumps.

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?  
   Many had their lunches but a company of women had arranged to serve substantial meals for the benefit of the church.

31. What did you have to eat and drink?  
   Fowl, potatoes, carrots, bread, butter, pies, cakes, home made lemonade and coffee.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?  
   Immediately after church services and during afternoon up to about 7 p.m.

In our church, jumps.

31. What did you have to eat and drink? Fowl, potatoes, carrots, bread, butter, pies, cakes, homemade lemonade and coffee.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? Immediately after church services and during afternoon up to about 7 p.m.
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

The writer, in looking for railroad ties that were piled where the railroad would come some day, had to cross a rugged terrain with two bronchos and a wagon. He was thrown up in the air and down on the ground. Could not act for the first few hours of the picnic.

Picnic was a success encouraging all and sundry to start again the next year. It was the beginning of a new era in meeting and organizing picnics.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

The picnics were not different than the ones above described but the attendance was larger and accordingly better prizes were given.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

In 1929 we celebrated the 25th anniversary of the coming of the first settlers. We had floats of a certain "chic" and more elaborate games including baseball, horse and oxen races, pig (greased) races etc.

From then on baseball tournaments seemed to take the cake and less foot races and horse races were held as the automobile became a mode of transportation.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

Young people.... foot races, bicycle races, horse races.

Men... foot races, horse races.

Women... games of chances and children races which were well attended.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams? Base ball

What year? 1915 How long did it continue? All the time more or less

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

There were no neighboring towns. No game could be arranged.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.). 1920 skating and a little hockey

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

Curling 1921

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.
